issues.description: Entry-point naming is inconsistent across artifacts: the template declares a global symbol 'start' and label 'start' (template_repository/helloWorld.asm lines 6-8) while the solution uses 'CMAIN' (solution_repository/helloWorld.asm lines 5-6). The template even contains a comment noting that the Makefile/tests expect 'main'. This mismatch between the symbol names the build/tests expect and the labels provided in template/solution can prevent the program from being linked/executed by the provided Makefile/tests and will confuse students about which label they must provide as the program entry point.
issues.suggested_fix: Unify the expected entry point name across all artifacts and the Makefile/tests. Options: (a) Change the template and solution labels to the entry symbol the Makefile/tests expect (e.g., rename 'start' and 'CMAIN' to 'main' and use 'global main'), or (b) update the Makefile/tests to accept the provided symbol (e.g., 'start' or 'CMAIN'). Prefer making the template and solution use the canonical entry point used by the build system (for example 'main') so students clearly know which label to implement.

issues.description: The program entry symbol (the label/name used as the program's entry point) is inconsistent across artifacts: the template defines and exports 'start' (global start / start:), the solution defines 'CMAIN' (global CMAIN / CMAIN:), and the template's own comment indicates the Makefile/tests expect 'main'. This creates confusion for students about which label to use as the program entry point and may cause builds/tests to fail even if the intended functional fix (ecc -> ecx) is applied.
issues.suggested_fix: Unify the entry symbol name across all artifacts. For example, use 'main' everywhere: change the template's 'global start' and 'start:' to 'global main' / 'main:', and change the solution's 'global CMAIN' / 'CMAIN:' to 'global main' / 'main:'. Alternatively, update the Makefile/tests to expect the chosen symbol (e.g., CMAIN) and update the template comment accordingly. Ensure the problem statement or repository README documents the expected entry symbol.
